questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a persistent cough and fever for the past month. He has a history of working in construction and has been exposed to soil and bird droppings. A bronchoalveolar lavage is performed, and microbial elements are observed under the microscope. His urine antigen test for the causative agent is positive and a histopathological image is shown as below. Which of the following structures is most likely observed?

choices.text: Chitin and glucan in the cell wall

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chitin and glucan in the cell wall

 

Explanation:

  • This is a case of Histoplasma capsulatum infection which is a fungus and fungi have cell walls composed of chitin and glucans.
    • The patient has a history of working in construction and being exposed to soil and bird droppings.
    • His symptoms, including a persistent cough and fever, align with pulmonary histoplasmosis.
    • Histoplasma can be detected by urine antigen test.
    • Histopathological examination shows a Giemsa-stained tissue smear with macrophages containing phagocytosed yeast forms of the fungus.

Giemsa-stained tissue smear shows a macrophage with phagocytosed H. capsulatum yeast forms.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female presents with a persistent cough and fever after returning from a trip. A laboratory workup reveals a fungal infection. The fungus is dimorphic in nature. Which of the following cannot be the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

Explanation:

  • Aspergillus species do not exhibit dimorphism.
  • They exist only as moulds in their environmental form and do not switch to a yeast form at body temperature as is seen in dimorphic fungi.

(Mnemonic: bodY temperature -Yeast)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a chronic ulcer on her leg that has been slowly expanding over several months. She has a history of gardening and often works with soil. The physician suspects a subcutaneous mycosis. Which of the following conditions is not classified in the same group as the suspected infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Tinea Versicolor

 

Explanation:

Tinea versicolor is a superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia and primarily affects the skin's outer layers, not classified as a subcutaneous mycosis.

 

Classification

Examples

Superficial Mycosis
  • Tinea Versicolor (Malassezia species)
  • Dermatophytes (Trichophyton, Microsporum, Epidermophyton)

Subcutaneous Mycosis (Option A, B, and D)
  • Mycetoma (Madurella species)
  • Rhinosporidiosis (Rhinosporidium seeberi)
  • Chromoblastomycosis (Fonsecaea pedrosi, Phialophora, Cladophialophora)
  • Sporotrichosis (Sporothrix schenckii)

Deep Mycosis/Systemic Mycosis
  • Dimorphic fungi
    • Histoplasma
    • Penicillium marneffei
    • Coccidioides
    • Sporothrix
    • Blastomyces
  • Opportunistic infections
    • Candida
    • Cryptococcus

questions.text: Which of the following statements about KOH preparation for identifying fungal elements is incorrect?

choices.text: Suitable for samples from skin, hair, and nails.
Percentage of KOH can be increased depending on the nature of the specimen.
Procedure involves placing the specimen in a drop of 10% KOH
KOH can be used for urine samples

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) KOH can be used for urine samples.

Explanation:

KOH preparation is not suitable for urine samples; it is primarily used for specimens from skin, hair, and nails, which contain keratin.

Direct Examination of Fungal Specimens

1. KOH Preparation

  • Samples: All samples except urine, CSF, blood, serum
  • Procedure:
    • Place the specimen in a drop of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) on a microscope slide (Option C)
    • Cover with a coverslip and gently heat the slide.
    • Examine under a microscope.
  • Purpose:
    • KOH digests keratin
    • Direct demonstration of fungal morphology
      • Hyphae, pseudohyphae, yeast cells
  • Key points:
    • Ideal for samples from skin, hair, and nails (Option A)
    • After digestion, hyphae become visible under the microscope
    • 10% clears tissue materials and makes the background clear
    • The percentage of KOH can be increased according to the nature of the specimen (20%,40% such as nails, takes longer time to dissolve) (Option B)

2. KOH with Calcofluor White

  • Procedure:
    • Add a drop of Calcofluor White solution to the KOH preparation before placing the coverslip.
  • Purpose:
    • Calcofluor White binds to fungal components, causing them to fluoresce bright green when exposed to UV light.
  • Benefits:
    • Enhances visibility of fungal elements, making identification easier.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with HIV presents with symptoms of fever, headache, and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture is performed, and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is sent for analysis. Which stain is most appropriate for identifying specific organisms in this CSF sample?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) India Ink

 

Explanation:

 

  • The likely diagnosis in this case is cryptococcal meningitis.
  • In patients with HIV, cryptococcal meningitis is a common opportunistic infection, making India Ink particularly relevant for diagnosis.

Stain

Description
 

Mycology lab

Calcofluor White
  • Fluorochrome binds to glucans and chitin in the fungal cell wall, enhancing visualization of fungal elements.

Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LCB)
  • Stains chitin in the fungal cell wall
  • Allows visualisation after scraping or tape preparation from cultures.
 

Pathology

Hematoxylin and Eosin (H&E)
  • Used primarily in pathology to visualize host cell responses to fungi
  • Does not stain most fungi, except some like Aspergillus spp. and Mucorales.

Grocott Methenamine Silver (GMS)
  • Stains fungal cell walls black, providing clear contrast for identifying fungi in tissue samples.

Periodic Acid-Schiff (PAS)
  • Stains the polysaccharide components of the fungal cell walls magenta
  • Useful for detecting fungal elements in histological samples.
 

Selected specific stains

India Ink
  • A "negative" stain outlining the polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus spp
  • Less sensitive than antigen detection for cryptococcal meningitis.

Mucicarmine
  • Stains the mucopolysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus spp.; can also stain Blastomyces and Rhinosporidium.

Fontana-Masson
  • Silver stain is used to detect melanin pigment in cell walls of Cryptococcus and pheoid moulds.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the role of mucicarmine in diagnosing Cryptococcus neoformans?

choices.text: Mucicarmine is the only stain that can identify Cryptococcus species in all clinical samples
Mucicarmine specifically stains the polysaccharide capsule, aiding in the identification of encapsulated Cryptococcus neoformans
Mucicarmine is equally effective for both encapsulated and capsule-deficient Cryptococcus strains
Mucicarmine is only useful when Cryptococcus neoformans cultures are positive

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mucicarmine specifically stains the polysaccharide capsule, aiding in the identification of encapsulated Cryptococcus neoformans.

 

Explanation:

Mucicarmine is used to stain the polysaccharide capsule of C. neoformans, which is essential for identifying encapsulated forms in clinical samples.

 

Role of Mucicarmine in Diagnosing Cryptococcus neoformans:

  • Primary Use: Stains the polysaccharide capsule of Cryptococcus neoformans, aiding diagnosis in immunocompromised patients.
  • Importance: Essential for identifying encapsulated forms, especially when other diagnostic methods are insufficient.

 

Key Diagnostic Roles of Mucicarmine:

Role

Description

Capsule Visualization

Stains the Cryptococcus capsule, which is a major virulence factor and critical for organism identification.

Comparison with Other Stains

Less effective with capsule-deficient strains; alternative stains like Fontana-Masson silver may be needed.

Clinical Relevance

Valuable when fungal cultures are negative or unavailable, especially when combined with other fungal stains.

Limitations

Not reliable for all Cryptococcus strains; complementary tests are necessary for accurate diagnosis.

 

Summary:

  • Diagnostic Aid: Useful in confirming cryptococcosis, particularly for encapsulated C. neoformans.
  • Limitations: Capsule-deficient strains may yield negative results with mucicarmine, requiring other stains for verification.

questions.text: Which of the following features of Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA) makes it particularly useful for culturing dermatophytes in clinical mycology?

choices.text: Neutral pH and presence of antibacterial agents
Acidic pH and addition of cycloheximide
Presence of growth factors to support bacterial and fungal growth
Neutral pH and enriched with glucose for rapid bacterial growth

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acidic pH and addition of cycloheximide

 

Explanation:

SDA has an acidic pH, favouring fungal growth over bacterial growth. The addition of cycloheximide further increases specificity by inhibiting non-dermatophytic fungi, making it ideal for dermatophytes.

 

Sabouraud Dextrose Agar (SDA) in Mycology:

  • Purpose: Used to culture fungi, especially dermatophytes (e.g., Trichophyton rubrum). (Option C ruled out)
  • pH: Acidic (pH 5.4), favouring fungal growth. (Options A&D ruled out)
  • Additives:
    • Chloramphenicol: Prevents bacterial contamination.
    • Cycloheximide: Inhibits growth of non-dermatophytic fungi, enhancing specificity.
  • Temperature for Culturing:
    • Incubation at room temperature (22°C) and 37°C to observe growth characteristics.

Fungal Identification on SDA:

 

Identification Method

Description

Macroscopic Features

Observed for colony colour, texture, growth rate, and appearance on both sides of the culture plate

  • Cryptococcus: Off-white mucoid colony
  • Candida: Creamy white pasty colony
  • Histoplasma: White cotton growth

Microscopic Examination

Techniques include teased mounts, cellophane tape mounts, and slide cultures; lactophenol cotton blue stain is used.

questions.text: A sample from a patient with suspected cryptococcosis is cultured on birdseed agar. What is the main purpose of using birdseed agar in this case?

choices.text: To inhibit bacterial growth and favour fungal growth
To selectively isolate Candida species from other fungi
To promote the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans through melanin production
To enhance the growth rate of all fungal species by providing additional nutrients

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) To promote the identification of Cryptococcus neoformans through melanin production

 

Explanation:

Bird seed agar is used to identify Cryptococcus neoformans, as this species produces melanin on the medium, resulting in a characteristic dark brown or black colour.

 

Other Cultures in Mycology:

Czapek-Dox Medium:

  • Used for isolating and cultivating a wide range of fungi, particularly nutrient-demanding species.
  • Chemically defined, allowing for precise study of fungal physiology and metabolism.

Bird Seed Agar:

  • Specifically designed for isolating and identifying Cryptococcus neoformans & gatti. (Options A&B ruled out)
  • Contains Niger seeds, which facilitate melanin production in Cryptococcus neoformans, leading to brown to black pigmented colonies. (Option D ruled out)
  •  

Corn Meal Agar:

  • Stimulates sporulation and reveals morphological characteristics of fungi, especially yeasts like Candida albicans and Candida dubinensis.
  • Simple medium made from corn meal extract; Tween 80 can be added to enhance chlamydospore production for identification.

Note: Non-specific media, like blood agar, can be adapted for fungal use with antibacterials.

Incubation Temperatures: Cultures are incubated at 22°C (room temperature) and 37°C to observe growth patterns and aid in species differentiation.

 

Fungal Culture Techniques:

 

Technique

Purpose

Macroscopic Clues

Growth rate, texture, and colour help in identifying fungal species.

Microscopic Analysis

Reveals fungal morphology through mounts and stains, detailing hyphae, conidia.


 

Importance of Fungal Cultures:

 

Aspect

Description

Definitive Diagnosis

Confirms fungal species responsible for infection, guiding specific treatments.

Species Differentiation

Distinguishes species by growth and microscopic traits, aiding in understanding fungi's role.

Antifungal Susceptibility Testing

Determines fungal sensitivity to antifungals, guiding effective therapy.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of using potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation in clinical specimens?

choices.text: Enhance the visibility of fungi by staining
Digest keratin and reveal fungal structures

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Digest keratin and reveal fungal structures

 

Explanation:

KOH preparation dissolves keratin, allowing fungal elements to be clearly visible under the microscope.

 

Detection Methods for Fungi Beyond Culture Media:

 

Method

Description

Use

Direct Microscopic Examination

KOH Preparation

Dissolves keratin in clinical specimens (e.g., skin scrapings, nail clippings) to visualise fungal elements.

Diagnosing dermatophyte infections

Calcofluor White Staining

Enhances fungal visibility by binding to chitin in cell walls, causing them to fluoresce under UV light. (Option A ruled out)

Observing fungal morphology

Gram Stain

Traditionally for bacterial identification, also useful for yeasts, which typically stain Gram-positive (purple).

Detecting certain fungi

India Ink Preparation

Negative staining method for encapsulated yeasts (e.g., Cryptococcus neoformans), revealing a clear halo around cells.

Identifying encapsulated yeasts

Methenamine Silver and PAS Staining

Histochemical techniques that stain fungi black (methenamine) or magenta (PAS) in tissue sections.

Highlighting fungi in tissues

Lactophenol Cotton Blue (LCB) Mount

Enhances contrast in teased fungal colonies for morphological observation.

Microscopic examination of fungi

Serology

Antibody Detection

Identifies antibodies produced by the host in response to fungi using methods like ELISA. (Option C ruled out)

Tracking immune response to fungal infections

Antigen Detection

Detects fungal antigens in body fluids using techniques such as latex agglutination tests.

Identifying fungal presence in the body

Skin Tests

Delayed-Type Hypersensitivity (DTH)

Assesses previous exposure to fungi through localised reactions to injected antigens.

Evaluating past fungal exposure

Newer Rapid Diagnostic Tests

Nucleic Acid Hybridisation

Uses labelled DNA probes for rapid fungal DNA detection in clinical samples.

Quick identification of fungal pathogens

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

Amplifies specific fungal DNA sequences, enabling early diagnosis even with low fungal loads. (Option D ruled out)

Early detection of fungal infections
